storyTitle: As Attendance Manager, I want to manually input attendance records to achieve complete and accurate attendance data

testCases.title: Validate successful manual attendance record creation
preconditions: User has Attendance Manager role with manual input permissions
User is logged into the attendance system
At least one active employee exists in the system
Attendance database is accessible and operational

steps.action: Manager navigates to manual attendance input page by clicking on 'Manual Attendance' menu option
steps.expectedResult: Manual attendance input form is displayed with fields for employee selection, date, time, and attendance details

steps.action: Manager selects a valid employee from the dropdown list
steps.expectedResult: Employee is selected and displayed in the form without errors

steps.action: Manager enters valid date in the date field (e.g., current date)
steps.expectedResult: Date is accepted and displayed in correct format

steps.action: Manager enters valid check-in time (e.g., 09:00 AM) and check-out time (e.g., 05:00 PM)
steps.expectedResult: Time values are accepted and displayed in correct format without validation errors

steps.action: Manager enters any additional attendance details or notes in the remarks field
steps.expectedResult: Form accepts all data without errors and all fields show entered values

steps.action: Manager clicks the 'Submit' button to save the attendance record
steps.expectedResult: System processes the request within 3 seconds, attendance record is saved to the database, and a success confirmation message is displayed (e.g., 'Attendance record created successfully')

steps.action: Manager verifies the newly created record appears in the attendance list for the selected employee and date
steps.expectedResult: Attendance record is visible in the system with all entered details displayed correctly

postconditions: New attendance record is saved in the attendance database
Audit log entry is created for the manual attendance addition
Attendance record is available for reporting and queries
Form is cleared and ready for next entry

testCases.title: Verify audit logging on manual attendance edits
preconditions: User has Attendance Manager role with edit permissions
User is logged into the attendance system
At least one existing attendance record is available in the system
Admin user account exists with audit log access permissions
Audit logging functionality is enabled and operational

steps.action: Manager navigates to the attendance records list and selects an existing attendance record to edit
steps.expectedResult: Edit form is displayed with current attendance data pre-populated in all fields (employee name, date, check-in time, check-out time)

steps.action: Manager modifies the check-in time from the original value to a new valid time (e.g., from 09:00 AM to 09:15 AM)
steps.expectedResult: Modified time is accepted and displayed in the field without validation errors

steps.action: Manager clicks the 'Save' or 'Update' button to submit the changes
steps.expectedResult: System saves the modified attendance record within 3 seconds and displays a confirmation message (e.g., 'Attendance record updated successfully')

steps.action: Manager logs out and Admin user logs into the system
steps.expectedResult: Admin is successfully logged in and dashboard is displayed

steps.action: Admin navigates to the audit logs section and filters for the edited attendance record
steps.expectedResult: Audit log displays the entry showing the manager's username, timestamp of the change, original values, modified values, and action type (Edit)

steps.action: Admin verifies all audit details are complete and accurate
steps.expectedResult: Audit log shows complete information: user who made the change, exact timestamp, field changed (check-in time), old value (09:00 AM), new value (09:15 AM), and employee identifier

postconditions: Attendance record is updated with new values in the database
Complete audit trail entry exists with all change details
Original values are preserved in audit history
Audit log is accessible to authorized users

testCases.title: Ensure access control for manual attendance input
preconditions: Two user accounts exist: one with Attendance Manager role and one without manual input permissions
Both users have valid login credentials
Manual attendance input functionality is protected by role-based access control
System is operational and accessible

steps.action: Non-authorized user (e.g., regular employee or user without manager role) logs into the system
steps.expectedResult: User is successfully logged in and redirected to their default dashboard

steps.action: Non-authorized user attempts to access the manual attendance input page by navigating to the URL or menu option
steps.expectedResult: System denies access and displays an error message (e.g., 'Access Denied: You do not have permission to access this page' or 'Unauthorized Access')

steps.action: Non-authorized user verifies that manual attendance input menu option is not visible or is disabled in their interface
steps.expectedResult: Manual attendance input option is either hidden or displayed as disabled/grayed out

steps.action: Non-authorized user logs out of the system
steps.expectedResult: User is successfully logged out and redirected to login page

steps.action: Authorized manager logs into the system with valid credentials
steps.expectedResult: Manager is successfully logged in and dashboard is displayed

steps.action: Authorized manager navigates to the manual attendance input page
steps.expectedResult: Manual attendance input page is accessible and the input form is displayed with all fields functional

steps.action: Manager selects an employee, enters valid date and time details, and clicks 'Submit'
steps.expectedResult: System accepts the submission, processes within 3 seconds, saves the attendance record, and displays success confirmation message

steps.action: Manager verifies the record is saved by checking the attendance list
steps.expectedResult: Newly created attendance record is visible in the system with correct details

postconditions: Non-authorized user remains unable to access manual attendance input functionality
Authorized manager successfully created attendance record
Access control rules are enforced and validated
Security audit log may contain access denial attempt

storyTitle: As Attendance Manager, I want to audit manual attendance changes to achieve accountability and data integrity

testCases.title: Validate audit logging on manual attendance changes
preconditions: User has Attendance Manager role with edit permissions
Manager is logged into the attendance system
At least one existing manual attendance record is available
Authorized user account exists with audit log access permissions
Audit logging system is operational and configured
Unauthorized user account exists without audit log access

steps.action: Manager navigates to the attendance records list and selects an existing manual attendance record to edit
steps.expectedResult: Edit form is displayed with current attendance data pre-populated

steps.action: Manager modifies the attendance time (e.g., changes check-in from 09:00 AM to 09:30 AM)
steps.expectedResult: Modified time is accepted and displayed in the field

steps.action: System prompts manager to provide a reason for the change in a mandatory text field
steps.expectedResult: Reason for change dialog or field is displayed and marked as required

steps.action: Manager enters a valid reason for the change (e.g., 'Correcting biometric failure entry')
steps.expectedResult: Reason is accepted and displayed in the field without errors

steps.action: Manager clicks 'Save' or 'Submit' button to save the changes
steps.expectedResult: System saves the modified attendance record and logs audit details within 1 second, displaying a success confirmation message

steps.action: Manager logs out and authorized user with audit access logs into the system
steps.expectedResult: Authorized user is successfully logged in and dashboard is displayed

steps.action: Authorized user navigates to the audit logs section and searches for the recently modified attendance record
steps.expectedResult: Audit logs page is displayed with search and filter options

steps.action: Authorized user views the audit log entry for the modified record
steps.expectedResult: Audit log displays complete details: manager's username, exact timestamp of change, employee identifier, field modified, old value, new value, and reason for change ('Correcting biometric failure entry')

steps.action: Authorized user logs out and unauthorized user attempts to log in
steps.expectedResult: Unauthorized user is successfully logged in to their account

steps.action: Unauthorized user attempts to access the audit logs section by navigating to the URL or menu
steps.expectedResult: System denies access and displays an error message (e.g., 'Access Denied: You do not have permission to view audit logs')

steps.action: Unauthorized user verifies that audit logs menu option is not visible in their interface
steps.expectedResult: Audit logs option is either hidden or displayed as disabled in the navigation menu

postconditions: Attendance record is updated with new values in the database
Complete audit trail entry exists with user, timestamp, reason, and all change details
Audit log is accessible only to authorized users
Unauthorized access attempts are blocked
Audit logging completed within 1 second of change

testCases.title: Ensure reason for change is mandatory
preconditions: User has Attendance Manager role with edit permissions
Manager is logged into the attendance system
At least one existing manual attendance record is available for editing
Reason for change field is configured as mandatory
System validation is enabled

steps.action: Manager navigates to the attendance records list and selects an existing manual attendance record to edit
steps.expectedResult: Edit form is displayed with current attendance data pre-populated in all fields

steps.action: Manager modifies the attendance time (e.g., changes check-out time from 05:00 PM to 06:00 PM)
steps.expectedResult: Modified time is accepted and displayed in the field

steps.action: System displays the reason for change field marked as mandatory (with asterisk or required indicator)
steps.expectedResult: Reason for change field is visible and clearly marked as required

steps.action: Manager leaves the reason for change field empty and attempts to click 'Save' or 'Submit' button
steps.expectedResult: System prevents the save operation and displays a validation error message (e.g., 'Reason for change is required' or 'Please provide a reason for this modification')

steps.action: Manager verifies that the attendance record has not been saved by checking the record details
steps.expectedResult: Attendance record still shows the original values and modifications are not saved

steps.action: Manager enters a valid reason for the change in the reason field (e.g., 'Employee worked overtime')
steps.expectedResult: Reason is accepted and displayed in the field, validation error is cleared

steps.action: Manager clicks 'Save' or 'Submit' button again with the reason provided
steps.expectedResult: System accepts the submission, saves the modified attendance record within 3 seconds, logs audit details within 1 second, and displays a success confirmation message

steps.action: Manager verifies the updated record appears in the attendance list with the new values
steps.expectedResult: Attendance record is updated and displays the new check-out time (06:00 PM)

steps.action: Manager or authorized user checks the audit log for this change
steps.expectedResult: Audit log entry exists showing the manager's username, timestamp, old value, new value, and the provided reason ('Employee worked overtime')

postconditions: Attendance record is updated only after reason is provided
Complete audit trail entry exists with mandatory reason field populated
System validation for mandatory reason field is confirmed working
Data integrity is maintained through mandatory audit reason

storyTitle: As Employee, I want to view my attendance records to achieve transparency and self-service

testCases.title: Validate employee attendance record viewing
preconditions: Employee has valid login credentials
Employee has existing attendance records in the system
Self-service portal is accessible and operational
Employee is authenticated and authorized to access the portal

steps.action: Employee navigates to the self-service portal URL and enters valid username and password, then clicks login button
steps.expectedResult: Portal home page is displayed with employee name and navigation menu visible

steps.action: Employee clicks on the 'Attendance' or 'My Attendance' menu option from the navigation menu
steps.expectedResult: Attendance records page is displayed showing all attendance records with timestamps, source (biometric/manual), and date information in a tabular format

steps.action: Employee selects a start date and end date from the date range filter controls and clicks 'Apply' or 'Filter' button
steps.expectedResult: Attendance records are filtered and only records within the selected date range are displayed on the screen

postconditions: Employee remains logged into the portal
Filtered attendance records are displayed on screen
No data modifications have occurred

testCases.title: Verify attendance data export functionality
preconditions: Employee is logged into the self-service portal
Employee has navigated to the attendance section
Attendance records are visible on screen
Browser allows file downloads

steps.action: Employee views the attendance records displayed on the screen and verifies records are visible
steps.expectedResult: Attendance records are displayed on screen with all relevant columns including date, time, source, and status

steps.action: Employee locates and clicks the 'Export' or 'Download CSV' button on the attendance page
steps.expectedResult: CSV file is automatically downloaded to the default download location with filename containing 'attendance' and current date, and the file contains all displayed attendance records with correct data matching the on-screen display

postconditions: CSV file is saved in the downloads folder
CSV file contains accurate attendance data matching screen display
Employee remains on the attendance page
No changes to attendance data in the system

testCases.title: Ensure access control for attendance data
preconditions: Employee is logged into the self-service portal
Multiple employees exist in the system with different employee IDs
Each employee has their own attendance records
System has proper authentication and authorization mechanisms in place

steps.action: Employee manually modifies the URL in the browser address bar to include another employee's ID (e.g., changing /attendance/employee/123 to /attendance/employee/456) and presses Enter
steps.expectedResult: System displays 'Access Denied' or '403 Forbidden' error message and does not display the other employee's attendance data

steps.action: Employee navigates back to their own attendance section using the proper navigation menu or by entering their correct employee ID in the URL
steps.expectedResult: Employee's own attendance data is displayed correctly with all records, timestamps, and source information visible and accurate

postconditions: Employee can only view their own attendance data
Unauthorized access attempt is logged in system audit trail
No data breach has occurred
Employee session remains active and valid

storyTitle: As Attendance Manager, I want to validate manual attendance inputs to achieve data accuracy and prevent errors

testCases.title: Validate rejection of manual attendance with invalid employee ID
preconditions: Attendance Manager is logged into the system with appropriate permissions
Manual attendance entry form is accessible
Employee database contains valid employee records
System validation rules are active and configured

steps.action: Manager navigates to manual attendance entry form and enters a non-existent employee ID (e.g., 'EMP99999') in the employee ID field, then enters valid date and time, and attempts to submit
steps.expectedResult: System displays a validation error message such as 'Employee ID does not exist' or 'Invalid Employee ID' in red text near the employee ID field, and the submit button is disabled or submission is prevented

steps.action: Manager clears the invalid employee ID field and enters a valid, existing employee ID from the system
steps.expectedResult: Validation error message is cleared and removed from the screen, employee name is displayed (if applicable), and form fields become enabled for submission

steps.action: Manager verifies all other fields contain valid data and clicks the 'Submit' or 'Save' button
steps.expectedResult: Attendance record is saved successfully to the database, success confirmation message is displayed, and the form is either cleared or redirected to the attendance list page

postconditions: Valid attendance record is saved in the database
No invalid employee ID records exist in the system
Manager remains logged in and can perform additional operations
Audit log contains record of successful attendance entry

testCases.title: Verify detection of duplicate attendance entries
preconditions: Attendance Manager is logged into the system
Manual attendance entry form is accessible
An attendance record already exists for a specific employee at a specific date and time
Duplicate detection validation is enabled in the system

steps.action: Manager enters the same employee ID, date, and time as an existing attendance record in the manual attendance entry form and attempts to submit
steps.expectedResult: System rejects the duplicate entry and displays an error message such as 'Duplicate attendance record detected' or 'Attendance already exists for this employee at this time', preventing submission

steps.action: Manager modifies the time field to a unique value that does not conflict with existing records while keeping the same employee ID and date
steps.expectedResult: Duplicate validation error is cleared, validation passes, and no error messages are displayed on the form

steps.action: Manager clicks the 'Submit' or 'Save' button to save the attendance record
steps.expectedResult: Attendance record is saved successfully to the database, success confirmation message is displayed such as 'Attendance record saved successfully', and the new record appears in the attendance list

postconditions: No duplicate attendance records exist in the database
New unique attendance record is successfully saved
Data integrity is maintained
Manager can continue entering additional records

testCases.title: Ensure real-time validation feedback during manual input
preconditions: Attendance Manager is logged into the system
Manual attendance entry form is open and accessible
Real-time validation is enabled and configured
JavaScript is enabled in the browser

steps.action: Manager enters an invalid date format (e.g., '32/13/2023' or 'abc-def-ghij') in the date field and moves focus to another field or waits briefly
steps.expectedResult: Validation error message is displayed immediately (within 1 second) below or near the date field indicating 'Invalid date format' or 'Please enter date in DD/MM/YYYY format' in red text

steps.action: Manager clears the date field and enters a valid date format (e.g., '15/01/2024' or system-accepted format) and moves focus to another field
steps.expectedResult: Validation error message is immediately removed from the screen, the date field shows a success indicator (such as green border or checkmark), and no error messages are visible

postconditions: Form contains valid date format
No validation errors are displayed
Manager can proceed with completing the form
Real-time validation continues to function for other fields

storyTitle: As Attendance Manager, I want to handle biometric device failures by switching to manual attendance input to achieve uninterrupted attendance tracking

testCases.title: Validate detection and notification of biometric device failure
preconditions: User is logged in with Attendance Manager role
Biometric device is currently online and functioning
System monitoring is active and configured
Notification system is enabled
Manual attendance input feature is available in the system

steps.action: Simulate biometric device failure by disconnecting the device or stopping the device service
steps.expectedResult: System detects the biometric device failure within 1 minute of the simulated failure

steps.action: Verify that the system sends a notification to the attendance manager
steps.expectedResult: Attendance manager receives an alert notification promptly (within 1 minute) indicating biometric device failure with device details

steps.action: Navigate to the attendance input section and verify manual input mode availability
steps.expectedResult: Manual attendance input mode is automatically enabled and accessible to the manager

steps.action: Manager clicks on the option to switch to manual input mode
steps.expectedResult: System successfully switches to manual attendance input interface with all necessary fields available for data entry

postconditions: System is in manual attendance input mode
Biometric device status shows as offline/failed
Notification has been logged in the system
Manager can proceed with manual attendance entry

testCases.title: Verify logging of fallback events
preconditions: User is logged in with Attendance Manager role
System is in manual input mode due to biometric device failure
Biometric device failure has been detected and logged
Audit logging system is active and configured
At least one employee record exists for attendance entry

steps.action: Navigate to the manual attendance input interface
steps.expectedResult: Manual attendance input form is displayed with fields for employee ID, date, time, and attendance status

steps.action: Enter valid employee attendance data manually (employee ID, date, check-in time, check-out time)
steps.expectedResult: All fields accept the input data without validation errors

steps.action: Submit the manual attendance entry
steps.expectedResult: Attendance record is saved successfully and confirmation message is displayed

steps.action: Navigate to the audit log section and filter for fallback events
steps.expectedResult: System displays the fallback event log entry with accurate timestamp, manager user ID, employee ID, and fallback reason (biometric device failure)

steps.action: Verify the completeness of the audit log entry details
steps.expectedResult: Audit log contains all required information: event type (fallback), timestamp, user details (manager name/ID), device ID, and action performed (manual attendance entry)

postconditions: Manual attendance record is stored in the database
Fallback event is logged in the audit trail
Attendance data integrity is maintained
Log entry is available for compliance and reporting purposes

testCases.title: Ensure system resumes biometric capture after device restoration
preconditions: User is logged in with Attendance Manager role
System is currently in manual input mode due to biometric device failure
Biometric device is currently offline or disconnected
Manual attendance entries have been made during the failure period
System monitoring is actively checking device status

steps.action: Simulate biometric device restoration by reconnecting the device or restarting the device service
steps.expectedResult: Biometric device comes online and is accessible to the system

steps.action: Wait for the system to detect the restored device status
steps.expectedResult: System detects that the biometric device is online within 1 minute and updates the device status to 'Active' or 'Online'

steps.action: Verify that the system automatically disables manual input mode
steps.expectedResult: Manual attendance input mode is automatically disabled and the system displays a notification indicating biometric capture has resumed

steps.action: Navigate to the attendance capture interface
steps.expectedResult: Biometric attendance capture interface is active and ready to accept biometric inputs from employees

steps.action: Simulate a biometric attendance capture (fingerprint scan or face recognition)
steps.expectedResult: System successfully captures biometric attendance data and creates an attendance record automatically

steps.action: Check the audit log for device restoration event
steps.expectedResult: System has logged the device restoration event with timestamp and automatic mode switch details

postconditions: System is back in biometric attendance capture mode
Manual input mode is disabled
Biometric device status shows as online/active
Device restoration event is logged in audit trail
System is ready to process biometric attendance normally
